CLOSE-- One hand opens the oven, and, mittened by an apro a tray of perfectly baked pirozhoki, which the other hand fresh tray . . . slightly burning itself on a knuckle.
Agafia sucks her knuckle and checks what's cooking on the the cook-housekeeper.
He needs to come in if he's to wash himself.
A Kitchen Maid at the sink obediently dries her hands on dozing dog, Laska, pricks up her ears.
It's snowing. The Kitchen Maid, shawled, with a lantern, across the yard towards the cowshed, a short distance, an frozen door. Laska is at her heels, but is made to stay o
The herd stirs at the lantern light. The bull, Berkut, wi his nose, snorts as the girl goes by. At the back of the
Levin is midwifing, sleeves pulled back, blood and slime He is 34. His steward, Vasili, holds up a lantern. Levin the emerging forefeet.
Good girl . . . good girl, Pava.
The calf's head emerges.
Agafia Mishaylovna says dinner's like to spoil.
The calf enters the world like a diver. Levin is feeling pleasure.
. . . her father's colour.
Worth coming home for, Konstantin Dmitrich!
I stayed too long in Moscow.
The cow nuzzles and licks her calf.
Cleaned up, in a smock shirt, Levin bites hungrily into a He has a book on a book-rest. Agafia ladles soup for him. of family portraits look down on him.  LEVIN
. . . She's a beauty. That's twelve cows sired by Berkut!  AGAFIA
So one of you is doing what the good Lord made you for.
Levin evades, ducks into spooning up soup, finding his pl Agafia goes out. Alone, Levin closes the book and stares
CLOSE--Expert fingers scrape a cut-throat razor across a cheek . . . and again, skirting luxuriant facial hair on   TITLE OVER:
There is a door to the landing and a door to the bedroom.     5
Prince Stepan Oblonsky-- Stiva to his friends--is 34 and body. A barber comes in every morning to shave him. His v older and almost a friend. He holds up an enormous pear.  MATVEY
What should I do with this?
Oblonsky puts the barber on hold to have a look.  OBLONSKY
Where did you find it?  MATVEY
In your hat. Your Excellency.
Oblonsky thinks about it, lets the barber finish. He stan dressing gown.  OBLONSKY
Yes . . . I picked it up somewhere for Daria Alexandrovna and the children.
Matvey is ready with Oblonsky's shirt, which he puts over like a horse's collar.
TIME--DAY

There is a sloping lineup of five children, aged eight, f two, dressed and brushed for presentation to their mother Oblonsky, known as Dolly . . . who we now see is heavily ing by is a French governess, Mlle. Roland, and a Nurse. is buxom.    6
Dolly picks up the youngest, Vasya, to kiss him and hands Nurse, and kisses the others in ascending order.  DOLLY
Bonjour, Lili; bonjour, Masha; bonjour, Grisha; bonjour, Tanya.
Who's coming to see Grandmama?

head_text.subj: INT. OBLONSKY'S DRESSING ROOM, SAME TIME--

text: DAY
Oblonsky, dressed now and holding a cup of coffee, checks   OBLONSKY'S POV--

Dolly, in furs, the four youngest children and the Nurse, all wrapped up against the cold weather, have come out of waiting sleigh, as noisy as starlings, bickering, competi The Oblonsky's Coachman assists, with a rug to spread acr
Oblonsky hands his coffee to Matvey and lights a small ci to take a sugared almond from a dish of sweets, and leave
TIME--DAY
Tanya is at her lessons with Mlle. Roland. When Oblonsky' smiling round the door, Tanya jumps up and runs to him, g laughing, kissing his face, hanging on his neck.     7 OBLONSKY
My Tanruchoshka! Mind my cigar.
He pops the sugared almond into her mouth and puts a cons to his lips. Mlle. Roland, who has stood up for him, cluc  OBLONSKY (CONT'D)
Be good today. I'm off.

Tanya runs back to her seat and bends to her schoolbook. Mlle. Roland in the eye. He moves his head slightly, unmi ing her to come outside. Mlle. Roland moves her eyes at h reproach. Clearly, this is familiar ground. Oblonsky clos him.
mlle. roland (PAUSE)
Read the chapter carefully. I'll come back to test you on it . . . Read it twice.
CLOSE--Pretty fingers put on several rings, and then pick jade paper-knife to slit an envelope and withdraw a lette   TITLE OVER:
TIME--DAY
It is early in the day. Anna's maid, Annushka, has been d Annushka is young, loyal, modest.
Anna is at her dressing-table-bureau, which is host to at tographs of a small boy (Serozha) and a child's unframed "Maman." As she starts reading the letter, Anna's eyes fr

head_text.subj: FLASH BACK, VERY SHORT, ALMOST SUBLIMINAL--

text: Oblonsky and Mlle. Roland in a passionate embrace, vertic
Anna turns the page, reads on, concerned.

head_text.subj: FLASH BACK-- SHORT, A BEAT OR TWO--

text: Still kissing, Oblonsky hoists up her skirts.
Anna turns to the second page.     9
Oblonsky, coming in quietly and late from a night on the dressing room. He stops. He smiles a foolish apologetic s
Dolly is waiting for him, shocked, enraged, holding out a pink paper: a love note.
Anna speaks as in exasperation to a naughty child.  ANNA
Tsk, oh . . . Stiva!
ANNA
. . . and Dolly found a note from the governess.

Anna is speaking to her husband "confidentially." Karenin drains his coffee cup and hands it (as with Oblonsky and valet, Korney, who bows and withdraws. Karenin continues papers from his desk to his portfolio . . .
Which done, he nods to his private secretary, Mikhail Sly forward to receive it, bows and leaves.   10 KARENIN
Well . . . ?
Karenin is twenty years older than Anna and a senior figu ment. He has an unattractive reedy voice and is pleased w model of probity. He has the habit of cracking his knuckl  ANNA
Stiva wants me to come to Moscow . . . to persuade Dolly to forgive him.  KARENIN
I'm to be deprived of my wife so that adul- tery may be forgiven? I can't excuse him just because he's your brother.  ANNA
It's for Dolly's sake too.  KARENIN
(has to go) I have four committees today . . .

There is another interruption: Serozha, aged seven and a tutor, Vasily Lukich, enter for a ritual "good morning." frightened of his father, but the mother and son are in l straight to Serozha, her heart lifted, to hug him.  KARENIN (CONT'D)
Good, good!--I have the world waiting for me, there's never time to look at your exercises!     11 LUKICH
Sergei Alexeyich is doing very well, Your Excellency.  ANNA
(a button missing) Tsk-tsk, who put this shirt on you? Never mind. I'll come and hear you read.  KARENIN
Tomorrow, perhaps. Thank you, Lukich-- perhaps tomorrow.
Lukich bows. Anna goes with Serozha, relinquishing him fi the door on them.  ANNA
Alexei, do you think nine years of mar- riage and children should count for nothing against a . . . an infatuation?
Karenin cracks his knuckles, concedes.  KARENIN
No. Very well. (kisses her hand) But sin has a price, you may be sure of that.
HOUSE--DAY
Oblonsky has been bunking down on his couch. He moans and gets up and tries the door to the bedroom. It's locked. H    12 OBLONSKY (PITEOUSLY)
Dolly . . . please think of the children . . .
He listens hopefully. The other door, leading to the uppe violently by Dolly.  DOLLY
You think of the children! Their lives are ruined now!
She slams the door behind her.
TIME--DAY
Oblonsky comes out of his dressing room to see the main b slammed. He attempts to go in but the door is locked.  OBLONSKY
Oh, Dolly . . . I beg you . . .
Matvey come to the top of the stairs with a telegram.  MATVEY
Telegram. Should I send up the barber?  OBLONSKY
No, just the razor.
Oblonsky tears open the telegram.     13 MATVEY
Don't worry, sir, things will shape them- selves, you'll see.  OBLONSKY (RELIEVED)
My sister Anna's coming tomorrow. We're saved.

Inner doors open and Oblonsky comes out of his private of genial self. Everyone in the general office-- minor offic up for him and bows. Oblonsky is wearing government unifo coat with gold embroidery on the collar--instead of his o is helped out of one coat into the other.  DOORKEEPER
Some man came without an appointment, Your Excellency . . . waiting outside.
Oblonsky opens the door to look. Levin is sitting waiting ing a sheepskin coat, cap and scuffed boots.  OBLONSKY
Levin! Where did you disappear?
He seizes Levin and kisses him.  LEVIN (NERVOUS)
I'm very anxious to see you. I need your advice.    14 OBLONSKY
Well, then, come into my room.
Oblonsky leads Levin back through the general office, whe up again. Levin's sheepskin and boots attract curious gla  OBLONSKY (CONT'D)
This is my oldest friend, Konstantin Dmit- rich Levin! Someone send word I'll be a few minutes late.
Oblonsky leads Levin inside and closes the door.  OBLONSKY
I've been hard at it. Sit down.
Levin undoes his coat and sits down.  LEVIN
Hard at what exactly?  OBLONSKY
Why, we're overwhelmed with work!  LEVIN
Oh--paperwork.  OBLONSKY
Paperwork is the soul of Russia. Farming is only the stomach. When am I going to come and shoot some snipe?
Seeing the clothes Levin is wearing, he laughs.   15 OBLONSKY (CONT'D)
Oh, but look at you, in Western clothes you told me you'd never wear again. Some- thing's up.  LEVIN
Yes. I'm in love. I've come back to propose. Have you guessed who she is?  OBLONSKY
(rolls his eyes comically) I have a suspicion. Why didn't you propose when you were here?  LEVIN

I decided it was impossible. Kitty is of the heavens, an angel, and I am of the earth-- but then I thought and thought, and . . . there's no life for me without her! . . . Do I have a chance?  OBLONSKY
Of course you do. The Shcherbatskys are giving a soiree this evening. Get there early before the crowd. If I may suggest . . .  LEVIN
Anything! What?  OBLONSKY
New boots.  LEVIN
Right. Anything else?    16 OBLONSKY (HESITATES)
We'd better have dinner together.
Come on, we'll meet later at l'Angleterre. Or do you prefer the Hermitage?
Oblonsky ushers Levin back into the general office.
. . . Everyone stands up as before. The Doorkeeper produc coat and helps him into it.  OBLONSKY
No--five-thirty at l'Angleterre--I owe them more than the Hermitage, so it wouldn't be fair to withdraw my custom. (taking his hat) Boots, and a coat. And a proper hat.
He ushers Levin out.
Firstly, a Moscow street scene, busy with people going ab on foot and in conveyances.
Secondly, Levin approaches L'Angleterre in his new fur-co hat and boots.     17
NIGHT
Oblonsky and Levin preside over the debris of three dozen champagne in a bucket to hand. Oblonsky is in a maudlin m on champagne.  OBLONSKY

It's so unfair. You marry for love, you're a good husband. Children arrive. Years depart. And all of a sudden your wife is tired, her hair is thin, her body . . . while you yourself still have your . . . vigour . . . and you find yourself distracted by a pretty woman . . .  LEVIN
Forgive me, but I find that incomprehen- sible . . . As though I'd leave this restaurant and steal a roll from a baker's shop.  OBLONSKY
Well, you know, a freshly baked roll . . .  LEVIN
But I'm talking about love, and you're talk- ing about . . . your appetite.  OBLONSKY
Easily confused. Now look, do you know Count Vronsky?  LEVIN
Who? No. Why?    18 OBLONSKY
He's your rival. He turned up from St. Petersburg after you left.  LEVIN (AGHAST)
Who is he?  OBLONSKY (CHANGING TACK)
You don't have to worry about him. He's one of those rich, good-looking cavalry offi- cers who've got nothing to do but make love to pretty women . . .
A waiter arrives to remove the oyster shells, while an El a bowl of soup in front of Levin and a lobster in front o  OBLONSKY (CONT'D)
Cabbage soup?  ELDERLY WAITER
Potage aux choux a la Russe, as the gentle- man ordered.  LEVIN
It's what I wanted.
Oblonsky laughs. The Waiter departs.  LEVIN (CONT'D) (ANGRY)
Understand that for me, tonight is a ques- tion of life and death.    19 OBLONSKY
Oh, Kostya! Kitty would be mad to refuse you. And Dolly is on your side, you know. She says her sister Kitty was always meant to be your wife and will be.
Levin jumps up in elation, collects himself, and sits.  LEVIN
Dolly said that? I've always thought your Dolly's a gem.  OBLONSKY
Oh, she is, she is . . . (THOUGHTFULLY)
I loved her to distraction.

A little out of focus and further obscured by puffs of st of a locomotive and its tender plus a carriage or two, wi superstructure--the whole kit and caboodle turning out to table-top model railway--go by the Camera like a WIPE rev momentarily gigantic face of Anna . . . who is crouching the toy go by.
Serozha is at present snivelling.  SEROZHA
But why?    20 ANNA
Because that's where Aunt Dolly lives.  SEROZHA
But why?  ANNA (PATIENTLY)
I told you, Serozha. She's not well. I must go to see her.  SEROZHA
But why?  ANNA
Now, don't make Mama cry. I'll be back before you know, and bring you a present.  SEROZHA
Don't want a present. I want you to stay.
Anna is on the brink of tears.  ANNA
Oh . . . my little Kutik . . .  SEROZHA
What present?  ANNA
That's better.
She dabs her eyes.     21

Kapitonich, the Karenins' Hall Porter, an "old soldier," house to where a private carriage is waiting. The coachma Anna comes out with Annushka, who has a large soft bag co everything her mistress needs for the journey. Kapitonich door for them.
Anna has a window seat. Next to her is Annushka.
In the opposite window seat is Countess Vronsky, at sixty keep her youthful beauty. She has a lap dog (and perhaps walking cane). Next to her is her Maid.
Anna is not happy to be leaving. She holds a small framed zha, which she then puts away in her red bag. Countess Vr her. Anna wipes her eyes, explains.  ANNA
It's the first time I've left my little boy.  COUNTESS VRONSKY
So you are leaving your son and I am return- ing to mine. I am Countess Vronsky.
Anna knows the name.
countess vronsky (cont'd) I've been in St. Petersburg for the christen- ing of a granddaughter--my elder son mar- ried Princess Chirkov. You're a charming creature. Why don't I know you?   22 ANNA
I've never been in Moscow society, really.  COUNTESS VRONSKY
But you know my name?  ANNA
I've heard you mentioned . . .  COUNTESS VRONSKY
Talked about, you mean. Ah, love!
Anna, found out, smiles tentatively.  ANNA
Was it love?  COUNTESS VRONSKY
Always. My sons are ashamed of me. But I'd rather end up wishing I hadn't than end up wishing I had--wouldn't you?  ANNA
I . . . I don't know . . .
Anna looks at the snow on the window. She is unsettled by
A sleigh (i.e., a cab) brings Levin.     23
SAME TIME--NIGHT
The Hall Porter lets Levin into the house. A Footman take and coat. Levin is uneasy--he seems to be first to arrive come too early. He pulls his coat back from the Footman.  LEVIN
I'll come back.   UP ABOVE
Princess Ekaterina (Kitty) Shcherbatsky is eighteen. Eage arrived, she hurries from the direction of the reception into the entrance hall in time to see Levin snatch his ha Footman.  KITTY
Konstantin!  LEVIN
I'm too early.  KITTY (PLEASED)
No! Come up!   DOWN BELOW
Kitty runs off out of Levin's view. He flings his hat and man and runs up the stairs.     24
SAME TIME--NIGHT
Levin hurries in and finds Kitty seated prettily in a "re is alone.  KITTY
Look at me! I'm receiving for Papa and Maman who are late to dress. It's my first reception.
Levin plays along, kissing her hand elaborately.  LEVIN
Princess Ekaterina! Delighted, delighted!  KITTY ( FORMAL)
I'm so pleased you were able to be with us, Konstantin Dmitrich!  LEVIN (DROPPING IT)
Kitty . . . you look . . . you look--  KITTY
Stiva told us you were back. How long are you staying?  LEVIN
I don't know. It depends on you.  KITTY
On me?    25

He has got ahead of himself. Doors are flung open and the Princess Shcherbatsky, and a crowd of guests who have arr greeting each other. Levin has to make a quick decision, wrong one--to go on.  LEVIN
What I mean to say--I came with only one purpose--I want to--will you be my wife?
Kitty panics. A wave of Guests is almost upon her.  LEVIN (CONT'D)
I'm sorry--sorry--wrong moment--but will you?  KITTY
I can't. I'm sorry.
Kitty flees. Levin seems stunned, surrounded now by greet and servants with trays of drinks.  LEVIN
Yes. It was impossible.
Prince and Princess Shcherbatsky receive a young married set, Countess Nordston . . . and introduce Levin, who hea ing. He turns away, leaving the Countess hung out to dry.
Levin finds himself face to face with Burisov, a silky Of uniform, who introduces himself.  BURISOV
Burisov. Are you the brother of Nikolai Levin?    26 LEVIN
Yes.  BURISOV
He's in Moscow, he's staying at the Unicorn in Khitrovka.  LEVIN
How do you know?  BURISOV (SMILES)
It's the sort of thing I know.
He bows to Levin and turns away to greet someone.
Levin reacts, decides to leave. He makes for the door. He with someone, gives and receives an apology, and suddenly this man in Guards uniform must be. Levin turns.  LEVIN
Count Vronsky?  VRONSKY
Yes.
Levin pauses awkwardly. Vronsky hesitates, bows and conti witnesses Kitty seeing Vronsky approaching, and sees her Vronsky kisses her hand.  VRONSKY (CONT'D) (BANTERING)
Princess Kitty . . . It's been so long, and yet it seems like yesterday.
His banter is lost on her. She laughs happily.   27 KITTY
It was yesterday!
Levin turns away and leaves.

Levin comes out of the grand house where several coaches bled and angry with himself and the world, he takes off h considers putting his fist through it, but jams it back o cab comes along. Levin waves it down.
A mean street, an area of poverty and crime. Levin pays o
Levin goes up a dimly lit, dingy staircase. Snatches of M ING drift up the stairs.
Levin knocks at a door, then louder. The door is flung op Levin is the spirit of consumptive, bohemian radicalism. surprised.  LEVIN
It's Kostya.
Nikolai roars with laughter which turns to wheezing.   28 NIKOLAI
God, look at him! You look like a capitalist! (THEN SUSPICIOUSLY)
What do you want?  LEVIN
Nothing. I came to see you.
Nikolai goes back into the room, shouting for "Masha." Le

head_text.subj: INT. NIKOLAI'S ROOM, KHITROVA, SAME TIME--

text: NIGHT
Levin sees that he is in a tiny apartment. A Young Woman fearfully from the inner doorway.  LEVIN
Good evening, miss . . . madame . . .  NIKOLAI
Don't talk to her like that. It frightens her. You sound like a magistrate. (shouts at her) More vodka for my brother, quick about it.  LEVIN
I don't want anything.
Masha goes to Nikolai and whispers to him, calming him.  NIKOLAI
I'm all right.
He fills a wineglass with vodka and gulps it greedily.   29 NIKOLAI (CONT'D)
Who told you where to find me?  LEVIN
A colonel in the Third Department. They're watching you.  NIKOLAI
Good. They must think I'm dangerous.
Levin involuntarily smiles at the self-puffery.  NIKOLAI (CONT'D)
What have you got to smile about?  LEVIN
Nothing.  NIKOLAI
That's right. The day is coming. I gave up my birthright for it. You're on the wrong side of history. Not because privilege is immoral but because it's irrational.
Wheezing, he goes for the bottle again. Masha tries to ta appealing to Levin.  MASHA
He is sick.  NIKOLAI
Let go or I'll beat your lights out.
He pushes her away and pours himself more vodka.    30 NIKOLAI (CONT'D)
I took Mary Nikolova from a brothel but I consider her my wife. If her presence offends you you're free to leave. Are you married?  LEVIN
No.  NIKOLAI
Why not? Are you waiting to fall in love?  LEVIN
No.  NIKOLAI
Good. Romantic love will be the last illu- sion of the old order. You should marry one of your peasants.
Levin's reaction is almost violent, surprising Nikolai.  LEVIN
Yes. I damn well should!  NIKOLAI
(toasts, casually) The brotherhood of man.
Levin recovers himself. He takes out his wallet.  LEVIN
Nikolai, you have to see a doctor. Then come and stay with me at Pokrovskoe till you get your health back.    31 NIKOLAI (SCORNFULLY)
With my wife?
Levin becomes flustered.  LEVIN
If you . . . or go abroad to a spa. I'll send you more if that's what you . . .

Masha reaches for the money Levin has put on the table. N her hand away. He throws the banknotes at Levin. He cough a paroxysm. Levin tries to embrace him. Nikolai throws hi  LEVIN (CONT'D) (CRIES OUT)
What about the brotherhood of brothers?
Masha snatches up the banknotes.
There is a scattering of people of all classes on the pla arriving train.
By the entrance/exit gate, a Guards Officer stands holdin Stationmaster stands by. A strip of faded red carpet has planks.  STATIONMASTER
The private coach will stop opposite the carpet.
The Guards Officer nods. He sees Vronsky arriving.   32 VRONSKY
Hello, what's this?  GUARDS OFFICER
Austrian royalty on their honeymoon. I've got them for four days.  VRONSKY
Bad luck. What do they like? Art?  GUARDS OFFICER
Food.  VRONSKY
Here's the train.
TIME--DAY
Vronsky moves closer to the slowing train, scanning the w
The Guards Officer and the Stationmaster are disconcerted "private coach" stop seriously short (or long) behind lug  STATIONMASTER
I'll see to it.
He hurries away towards the engine.
Oblonsky hurries through, relieved not to be late.    33
Vronsky is saluted by his mother's Major Domo, a tall man a cockade.  MAJOR DOMO
Second carriage, Your Excellency. I'll see to the Countess's luggage and bring it on to the house.
Vronsky nods, and makes his way towards the second coach, flow of disembarked passengers.
The Stationmaster speaks to the Engine Driver.
The Guards Officer with the bouquet stands uncertainly wh passengers go past him.
The Royal Austrian Honeymooners peer anxiously through th
Countess Vronsky remains sitting. Annushka packs away Ann and pillow. Anna looks out of the window.    34 ANNA
I'll come back.

Anna moves to the door opening on to the "porch." Vronsky of entering. He steps back to allow her by. They barely e as she passes him, but, simultaneously, each of them look away quickly. His look lingers before he turns away to en
Anna, from her vantage point spots Oblonsky, calls to him with her bag, comes onto the porch and descends to follow
Anna steps down to the platform and embraces Oblonsky. Th to see each other.  ANNA (ACCUSINGLY)
You don't look ashamed.  OBLONSKY (CONTRITE)
I am, I really am.
Countess Vronsky remains in her seat. Vronsky bends at th ing at Oblonsky and Anna.     35 VRONSKY
Yes, of course. Oblonsky's sister . . . Karenina.  COUNTESS
Charmante, don't you think? (to her Maid) Wait for me in the carriage. I'll take Tosca.
She takes the dog. The Maid leaves with her bag.  VRONSKY
. . . You stayed longer in St. Petersburg.  COUNTESS VRONSKY
Long enough for you to start a little love affair, I hear.  VRONSKY
I can't think what you're referring to, Maman.
He glances back to the window, where Anna turns back to e

As Anna turns back, a Railwayman with a hammer for tappin is in her way. He steps back for her with a bow and a "Ma glances at him and moves past him. The man taps a wheel, ing sound which means the wheel is okay.
As Anna mounts the steps, a Train Guard looks up and down form, holding a green flag.    36
Anna enters from the porch.  ANNA
There, Countess, you have found your son and I have found my brother.  COUNTESS VRONSKY
Madame Karenin has a son, too. It's the first time they have been apart, so she frets about him.  VRONSKY
Excuse me for not recognizing you before.  COUNTESS VRONSKY
We passed the time telling each other about our sons.  ANNA
Yes, I've been hearing all about you.  VRONSKY
That must have been very boring for you.
The ringing sound of the wheel-tapper's hammer is faintly Anna's hesitation. Anna shuts off the gallantry.  ANNA
Au revoir, Countess.  COUNTESS VRONSKY
Au revoir, my dear. Let me kiss your pretty face.   37
Countess Vronsky does so. Anna turns to offer her hand to Vronsky takes her hand, the train lurches and moves, unst both.
Oblonsky-- and everyone still on the platform--is shocked scream and shouting. The train, having moved a few feet, hurries towards the scene of the accident, right opposite master overtakes him.
The Wheel-Tapper lies between the wheels, mangled.
Oblonsky joins the horrified onlookers. The Guards Office with his bouquet. Then Vronsky arrives. He turns to the G  VRONSKY
Keep your people inside until this has been cleared up.
Countess Vronsky, Vronsky, Anna and Oblonsky, Oblonsky al come towards the gate. A Porter follows with Anna's large boxes, etc. Annushka has the travelling bag.  OBLONSKY
. . . the sole support of a large family, they say.    38 ANNA
Can't anything be done for them?
Vronsky glances at her.  VRONSKY
Wait for me, Maman.
Vronsky retraces his steps.  COUNTESS VRONSKY (TO ANNA)
I've you to thank for that.
She knows her son. Anna hasn't understood, but when Oblon he sees Vronsky with the Stationmaster, taking money from  OBLONSKY
What a good fellow . . .
Anna catches on, doesn't like it.
ANNA
Have you known Count Vronsky long?  OBLONSKY
Did you like him? He's in love with Kitty.  ANNA
Oh . . . (PAUSE)
But we should be discussing you and Dolly.   39
She scolds him like a naughty boy.  ANNA (CONT'D)
What have you got to say for yourself?  OBLONSKY
I've said it all--on my knees--in tears . . . Now I need you to say it. I'm going to the office, so you'll have Dolly to yourself.  ANNA (SEVERELY)
Don't be home late.
MOSCOW--DAY
Dolly pours tea for Anna. Dolly smiles at her wanly-- bri  DOLLY
Kitty's coming by to see you. She's all grown-up, and a bit frightened of you--the belle of St. Petersburg society!  ANNA
Is that who I am?
Dolly . . . Stiva has told me.
Dolly bursts into tears. Anna embraces her.  ANNA (CONT'D)
Dolly, I'm sorry from the bottom of my heart.   40 DOLLY
I don't know what to do.  ANNA (SOOTHING)
I know, I know.  DOLLY
I can't bear to be with him. And he doesn't care, he's got what he wants.  ANNA
What he wants is you. He loves you, Dolly. You and the children are everything to him.  DOLLY
Are we? And there is room for a governess?  ANNA
That was shameful, disgraceful. But it was not love. It was the animal in man, not the soul. Stiva's remorse is from the soul.  DOLLY
What about me? Does his remorse make it easier for me?--  ANNA
I know you are suffering. But, Dolly, you must tell me . . . is there enough love left in your heart . . . enough to forgive him?  DOLLY
When I think of them together, I can't for- give him, no!   41 ANNA
My poor lamb. So you'd rather accept your fate . . .  DOLLY
My fate? (OUTRAGED)
But I haven't done anything! It's him WHO'S--  ANNA
Do you love him, Dolly?
Dolly nods tearfully.  ANNA (CONT'D)
You love him, and he loves you, but you can't forgive, so your lives must continue like this for ever, with both of you wretched.
She's winning.

Anna, Kitty, Tanya and Grisha are at a handsome card tabl board games, dominoes, cards, etc., are kept. There is a bricks, each with a letter printed in it. They are spelli alphabet bricks. Grisha is on Anna's lap pulling at her h business, including misspellings by Grisha, creates a noi mock-rebuke. Tanya at the same time is trying to pull a r finger.
Kitty is not at all frightened of Anna now; enraptured by    42 ANNA
Grisha, don't pull so hard, you're getting it all in a tangle--and look for another G for GRIGORI--
(She takes off her ring for Tanya) --here, darling, you can wear it till you go TO BED--

Dolly sits apart, embroidering. She looks up at the sound stairs, Oblonsky coming home. The children hear their fat the card table, running out to greet him. Dolly stands up ferent door, giving Anna a collusive glance.
Anna pushes aside the alphabet bricks.  ANNA (CONT'D)
Well, that's the end of that.  KITTY
Will you stay for the Bobrishchev's ball, Anna?  ANNA
Oh . . . I always feel dull at a ball.  KITTY
How can you ever be dull?
Oblonsky arrives in the doorway with Tanya and Grisha han  KITTY (CONT'D)
Stiva! Tell Anna she must come to the ball.  OBLONSKY
Of course she must.   43
He cocks an eye at Anna: how did it go with Dolly? Anna m upstairs.  ANNA
. . . and God go with you.
Kitty catches the moment.  OBLONSKY (LEAVING)
You can introduce me to your new governess.  TANYA
She's old! She's a hundred!
Which leaves Anna and Kitty alone.  ANNA
I know why you want me to come. You want everyone to be there because you're sure it's going to be your night.  KITTY
How did you know?
Anna's smile is her acting out a mock-mysteriousness.  ANNA
I know everything.
She has moved alphabet letters around to spell out VRONSK at Kitty's tearful, joyful nodding, genuinely happy for K  ANNA (CONT'D)
Oh, to be your age again . . . surrounded by that blue mist, like mist on the mountains   44
that clears slowly to reveal the terrifying, beautiful valley you must enter to become grown-up . . . I was eighteen too, when I got married . . .
A quiet note of regret hangs in the air between them for Anna dispels it.

With only a lamp or two lit, and the door open, Anna sits card table, with a neglected book, one hand playing idly bet bricks. Their pleasant clicks are the only sound as s thought. She closes her book, marking the place. She is g She hears the sound of the doorbell.
TIME--NIGHT
Vronsky has been let in spattered with snow.  SERVANT
. . . no, Your Excellency . . . He's just gone up. . . . The Princess retired early . . . Is there a message?
Vronsky glances up and sees Anna looking down. Their eyes passes. Vronsky is about to speak. Anna turns away and mo view, towards further stairs, with her book.  VRONSKY
No.    45
Levin is coming home in a sleigh, driven by his one-eyed He is huddled under a bearskin blanket. The house is in s

The sleigh overtakes a Peasant Woman, Serafina, walking t rying a big bundle of willow wands strapped to her back: woman with a handsome face. She stops and bows her head. her. She then looks him in the face.
Laska, barking joyfully, races from the house.

The bathhouse has a stove which heats water. There is a b instant steam, but not now. Levin, almost naked, lies on thoughtful, staring at something . . . no, at someone: Se ting on her clothes. Postcoitum. She has no angst. Dresse  LEVIN
Will you go to confession?
Serafina nods indifferently.  LEVIN (CONT'D)
God will forgive you.  SERAFINA
And you also, master. He is watching.  LEVIN
God forgive us then, for committing the act of love.
She nods without irony.   46 SERAFINA
He is merciful.  LEVIN
"Not according to my deserts, O Lord, but according to thy mercy"--that's a fine prayer. But I'm full of doubt. Sometimes I even doubt that God exists.  SERAFINA
How can there be anything if God didn't make it?  LEVIN
I don't know. One day science will tell us.  SERAFINA
That's sinful talk if the priest heard you.  LEVIN
Well, I won't go to confession.  SERAFINA (SHRUGS)
Your father built the church. You're con- fessed a while yet.
Levin feels outplayed.  SERAFINA (CONT'D)
Will you bring me something from Moscow?  LEVIN
What would you like?   47 SERAFINA
Soap, the kind wrapped in paper to look pretty, and smelling like for a proper lady.
Levin is touched. He nods.

head_text.subj: SOUND OVER--MUSIC OVERLAP WITH THE BALL.

text: Kitty enters the Ball, a proper lady.
This is a gilded affair, conducted by a Master of Ceremon and Hostess are positioned to welcome each guest. Dancing waltz.

Kitty and her parents enter the ballroom and are received Everything has come together for Kitty--her dress, her ha moment. She radiates happiness. An Officer stands aside t openly admiring Kitty, smoothing his moustache. A Youth h with his white tie hurries past but turns back to Kitty.  YOUTH
Kitty! May I have a waltz?  KITTY
You may, Boris. I'll save you the third just because it's your first ball.  YOUTH (THRILLED)
You're my first conquest.
The Master of Ceremonies, Korsunsky, arrives and without sweeps her into the waltz.   48 KORSUNSKY
It's a relaxation to dance with you, Princess.
Kitty sees Anna arriving with Oblonsky and gives a little God-given beauty.  KORSUNSKY (CONT'D)
But back to work! Where do you want to be taken?  KITTY
There.
Korsunsky waltzes her brilliantly through the dancers and rest in front of a small group including Anna and Oblonsk Kitty's train.  KORSUNSKY (BOWING)
So that your ankles may be seen.
Anna appraises Kitty at a glance and gives her a tiny nod marks. Kitty glows.  KITTY
How are you, Stiva?  OBLONSKY
Thanks to Anna, I am a happy man. Would you like to dance?  KITTY
No, ask Anna.     49 ANNA (DEMURS)
No . . . I don't . . .
She looks up and sees Vronsky coming straight towards her  ANNA (CONT'D)
Come on then.

Just as Vronsky is about to bow, she takes Oblonsky's arm her away. Kitty smiles for Vronsky but his eyes have foll ing she cut him. He remembers himself after an awkward hi mother and father are watching from afar. Vronsky obliges into the waltz.  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY
. . . this vile, idiotic matchmaking of yours . . .  PRINCESS SHCHERBATSKY
For goodness' sake, what have I done?  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY
Levin is a thousand times better than this Petersburg fop. If he had royal blood my daughter wouldn't need him!
Vronsky's mind is absent and the waltz ends after only a stand waiting for the music to start.  KITTY
Is anything the matter?     50 VRONSKY
No. You look . . . as lovely as ever, Princess Kitty.
The music starts and they dance on.
At the end of the waltz, Vronsky leaves Kitty with her mo departs. Princess Shcherbatsky is beginning to have doubt  KITTY (SHARPLY)
Don't ask me, Maman!
Boris the Youth pops up to claim his dance. Dancing, Kitt talking to a couple of Officers. She is anxious but not d
Grumpy Prince Shcherbatsky is dancing with Countess Nords  COUNTESS NORDSTON
He'll dance the mazurka with Kitty, you'll see. I call the mazurka the now-or-never.
Anna watches the dancing. She rejects an offer with a smi sky and to her discomfort Vronsky looks up and catches he

She turns away at once, and notices that ladies are curts bowing as the Host and Hostess escort an overweight but g couple towards a decorative buffet in an adjoining salon: royal honeymooners . . . attended by the Guards Officer f Anna stands and curtseys as they pass by into the salon . is roaring with laughter, champagne in hand.  AUSTRIAN PRINCESS
. . . we were shut up in the train for an hour!    51
Anna steals a sidelong glance towards Vronsky but he is n She looks for him among the dancers, smiles at Kitty goin enthusiastic, inexpert Boris.
Suddenly, Vronsky is at Anna's side.  VRONSKY
Dance with me.  ANNA (CALMLY)
I am not used to being spoken to like that by a man I met once at a railway station.  VRONSKY
I dare say, but if I'm not to dance with you, I'm getting out of this operetta and going home.  ANNA
Then, for Kitty's sake.
She gives him her hand.

Kitty looks for Vronsky, can't see him, then is taken aba Anna. Kitty watches Anna dancing. Anna says something whi Vronsky laugh. Anna laughs. Anna blossoms in front of Kit sky twirls Anna around and she comes smiling into his arm
It goes on like that. Kitty watches them from within the old men, from the wall. Anna and Vronsky dance slow, they gaily, solemnly, gazes locked.
Others are noticing too: Countess Nordston, Princess Shch eagle-eyed matrons. Anna, oblivious, has found a release   52
Countess Nordston finds Kitty sitting alone. Korsunsky an Mazurka.  COUNTESS NORDSTON
You're not dancing the mazurka? I won't have it.
She pulls Kitty to her feet.
countess nordston (cont'd) I'm engaged by General Glub--I give him to you.
Korsunsky supervises a large circle of couples who change round, with one couple dancing in the middle of the circl  KORSUNSKY
. . . the lady chooses a lady and a gentleman . . . !

The lady in the middle beckons to Anna and the man who, c ners, happens to be dancing with her. They enter the midd have their solo turn as a couple, while the original coup ference. Anna is flushed with pleasure. Among the surroun Vronsky has no eyes for his partner, only for Anna. Kitty Vronsky incredulous.  KORSUNSKY (CONT'D) (ADDRESSING ANNA)
. . . and the lady chooses a lady and a gentleman . . . !    53

Anna looks smilingly around the dancing circle and sees K at her. Anna "wakes up." Everything which made her drunk sober in the instant. She waits until the change of partn and Vronsky together. She beckons them into the middle. H expects to re-join the circumference with Anna, but she m and escapes through the circle, running towards the door.
With a howl and clatter, the St. Petersburg express seems the ballroom.   MONTAGE
An abstract, nightmarish, discordant noise of clattering accompanies unexplained flame--light on wood, glass, iron opens like a door on a blizzard of light, and slams shut.
Anna's face, eyes closed, floats ghostlike.

Anna comes to consciousness in the dimly lit carriage, ma seems like a hallucination. Wind and snow batter on the w Carriage Stoker, in long coat and cap, deals with the sto a thermometer on the wall. He leaves, opening the door to and slamming it behind him.
The train "speeds" (35 m.p.h.) through a blizzard.     54

Anna has a reading lamp hooked over her armrest, and a no a page with a paper-knife. But the book cannot hold her. without taking it in. She turns back a page and tries aga once she turns to the window where the dark reflection of at her. Kitty's face staring as she stared at Anna, betra
Anna turns away from the window. The Guard comes through letting in wind and snow, and shuts it. He walks through  GUARD
Bologoye! Fifteen minutes.
The train is slowing.

The train clanks to a halt at a small station. Anna (and get down from the train. She wears a heavy cloak. The win snowflakes through the station but the roof keeps off the the fresh air. Here and there, men are walking, smoking, She feels better.
A tall outline of a man in a greatcoat and military cap e flickering gloom. She catches her breath. He salutes her.  VRONSKY
Can I be of service to you?  ANNA
I didn't know you were . . . Why are you leaving?    55 VRONSKY
You know why. I have to be where you are. I can't not.  ANNA
This is wrong. If you're a good man, forget everything that happened, as I will.  VRONSKY
I'll never forget a single thing about you, not a word, not a gesture--  ANNA
That's enough!
She climbs the steps on to the porch. At the door to the The encounter has left her feeling elated and frightened.
The train arrives. Vronsky gets down from the train and s towards Anna's carriage. His German valet, Franz, runs up second class).  VRONSKY
Take the luggage home.
Franz runs back the other way. Vronsky walks on, then sto sees Karenin waiting on the platform, smiling and going f Anna down the steps. Kapitonich enters the carriage. Vron  ANNA (ANXIOUS)
Is Serozha all right?   56 KARENIN
Oh, is that all I get? Yes, he's quite well.
Vronsky steps forward. Anna knows he's there. She angles looking at him.  VRONSKY
Did you have a good night?
He bows to Karenin.  ANNA
Yes, quite comfortable. Count Vronsky.
Karenin extends a hand indifferently then dismisses Vrons Anna with him.  KARENIN
I have to get back to the Committee . . .
He walks Anna away.  KARENIN (CONT'D)
Well--were you a success?  ANNA
I? Oh--Dolly and Stiva . . . yes, I think so . . .
Vronsky watches them go.     57
DAY
A snowy St. Petersburg street. Vronsky arrives home by ca in an old apartment block.
TIME--DAY
Vronsky rings the doorbell. A Servant opens the door. A m "If it's someone demanding money, don't let him in!"  VRONSKY
I'll announce myself.
Veronsky enters the main room. The occupant of the flat i ant, Petritsky, wearing his greatcoat over shirt and trou  PETRITSKY
Vronsky! The master himself. Baroness, coffee from the new coffeepot for Count Vronsky.
Petritsky indicates a pretty young woman in satin.  PETRITSKY (CONT'D)
I hope you are pleased by this ornament to your quarters.
Vronsky bows and kisses her fingers.  BARONESS
I'll be off home if I'm in the way.    58 VRONSKY
You're at home where you are, Baroness.  BARONESS
Ah!--Pierre, you never say such pretty things to me. We were just discussing my husband. He won't divorce me, you see. And do you know why?  VRONSKY
No.  BARONESS
Because he likes eating off my family silver.  VRONSKY
Ah.  BARONESS
I want to bring an action. Just because I'm supposed to be unfaithful, I don't see why I have to eat off Pierre's crockery. Look at it.  VRONSKY
It's my crockery.  PETRITSKY
How was Moscow?  VRONSKY
Provincial.     59
NIGHT

Anna, her dress changed, lies on Serozha's bed, on her si his bedclothes scratching his back gently. He lies quietl with his eyes closed, his face inches from hers. In the d light she gazes at him for long moments.  SEROZHA (MUTTERS)
You've stopped.
She resumes scratching. He grunts contentedly.  SEROZHA (CONT'D) (SLEEPILY)
Thank you for my present.  ANNA
Sssh . . .
She kisses him and continues to lie there, gently scratch asleep. She removes her arm and restores his bedclothes.

There is a suite of rooms: the Bedroom connects to Anna's Room; and thence to Karenin's small Sitting Room/Dressing connects to the rest of the house. The rooms--like the wh by gas lamps but also by candles at key points.     60

head_text.subj: INT. KARENIN'S DRESSING ROOM, SAME TIME--

text: NIGHT
Korney, the Valet, gathers up a discarded shirt, etc. Kar gown is reading in a comfortable chair, by a candle lamp.
Anna is at her bureau. She frowns and tears up the letter
Karenin looks at the clock-- nearly midnight-- and closes blows out the candle. He comes to the boudoir announcing smile.  KARENIN
Time for bed!
Karenin comes to put his hand on Anna's shoulder.  ANNA
I'm writing to Dolly . . . and to Kitty.  KARENIN
You are . . . good.
Anna shakes her head and clasps his hand.     61
Candles each side of the bed. Karenin cracks his knuckles drawer and opens a tin box lying in the drawer.
Anna, disrobing, registers these sounds.  KARENIN
What are they saying in Moscow about the new Statute?  ANNA
What new Statute?
Karenin takes a contraceptive sheath, made from animal in usable) from the tin.  KARENIN
The new Statute I carried in Council.
Anna blows her candle out and gets into bed.  ANNA
No one mentioned it.  KARENIN
Ah. Really?
He comes to bed in his nightshirt.  KARENIN (CONT'D)
Here it made quite a sensation.
He gets into bed. Anna waits dead-eyed. Karenin blows his    62
MOSCOW--DAY
Kitty, a hollow-eyed version of herself, in a demure nigh on a chaise longue with her legs stretched out. The Famil tially removes one of her slippers as though it were an i  FAMILY DOCTOR
Forgive me, Princess, but I must . . .
With a silver "fork" the Doctor tests the sole of her foo is miserably going along with a farce she despises.
The Prince and Princess are hovering. The Princess flutte the Prince is in a temper.  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY
Am I the only one who knows what's wrong with her?
But a Celebrity Doctor, as shiny as his own gold watch wh ing, is bearing down on them, riding over a Footman's att him.  PRINCESS SHCHERBATSKY
Oh, thank God, doctor--my friends say you're the only one who can save her!  CELEBRITY DOCTOR
Possibly, Princess, possibly! At your service, Your Excellencies. Where is the patient?    63
Kitty is sobbing with shame: the Celebrity Doctor has str waist and is tapping her chest. The Family Doctor can't b himself.  CELEBRITY DOCTOR
Come, come, Princess, we are not backward people--I handle naked bodies every day. Deep breath now . . .
The Family Doctor and the parents are in a huddle. The Pr  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY
By God. I'll challenge the scoundrel!  FAMILY DOCTOR
It's the modern way . . .  PRINCESS SHCHERBATSKY
(to the Prince) You're not a doctor!  FAMILY DOCTOR
Her symptoms . . . loss of appetite, fast PULSE--  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY
Well, whose pulse wouldn't be fast if some brute of a--
The Celebrity Doctor comes briskly out of Kitty's room, c   64 CELEBRITY DOCTOR
Nervous palpitations. We must treat the nerves. A tubercular cavity is suspected, too soon to tell. Soden water every two hours. I must see her again tomorrow. (HE BOWS)
Prince! Princess!
He's gone. The Prince enters Kitty's room.
Kitty is humiliated and triple-wrapped against the violat  PRINCE SHCHERBATSKY
Don't you fret, my little Kate! You'll wake up one fine morning and say to yourself--"I feel well and happy and I'll go out for a walk with Papa!"
The Prince is mortified when Kitty's sobs redouble.

The social set Anna now moves in is the brilliant circle to the Court on one hand and to the demi-monde of artists leading light of this set is Princess Betsy Tverskaya, a Betsy's immediate circle includes Tuskevich, her "admirer
Anna lifts her eyes to see Vronsky in front of her, talki sees Anna and bows. She acknowledges him and kisses Betsy on, studying the next picture. Vronsky watches Anna move an eye at him.   65
A few rows of chairs in someone's reception room, a mixed a flashy pianist . . . Betsy with a "toy" dog on her lap, side, Anna on the other.
The dog yaps and sneezes. Betsy hands the dog to Tuskevic exit with the dog. As Tuskevich leaves, Vronsky comes in. She turns back to the piano. Betsy glances at her.

Anna and Betsy, on a bright snow-white day, are being dri park in Betsy's smart equipage . . . towards a horseman w them: Vronsky salutes the little carriage as it trots by looking straight ahead. Betsy acknowledges Vronsky's salu  BETSY
I want to give a small dinner before the opera. Is there anyone you would like me to ask?  ANNA
Yes . . . Yes, the Metropolitan Bishop of St. Petersburg.
Betsy laughs.
HOUSE--NIGHT
Annushka puts Anna's opera cloak over her shoulders, whil ready with Karenin's cloak and opera hat. Karenin comes d to join Anna. Kapitonich stands ready to let them out.   66 KARENIN
Countess Lydia tells me you haven't been to one of her evenings since you returned.  ANNA
The last one was to meet a missionary, the one before was for a lecture on the union of the Greek and Roman churches. (CLIMBS DOWN)
I'm sorry--I know you're fond of her. Come on, or we'll be late.
Kapitonich opens the door to let them out.
This is a small theatre with a "promenade" area where a g Officers of high and low rank mix together to enjoy the c comedians and the can-can girls. Vronsky is with his Comm Colonel Demin.  DEMIN
Here's the thing, Vronsky. A posting has come up and there's a promotion in it for you.  VRONSKY
Thank you, sir.  DEMIN
The garrison in Tashkent.     67 VRONSKY
Tashkent? But . . . I would like to stay in Peter, sir, if you don't mind.  DEMIN
I don't mind. But your mother . . .
The can-can music starts up, to many cheers. Demin claps Vronsky is angry.
An attendant takes Vronsky's coat and gives him a token f a performance going on within, resolving into applause as stairs.
Karenin, an escapee looking at his pocket watch, comes do down past Vronsky, looks back at him for a moment, and co

Vronsky enters the box as the performance prepares to res Tverskoy box, occupied by Princess Betsy and her husband, overweight and, strangely enough, looking at an antiquari ing white gloves. Vronsky bows to them and sits down next takes her opera glasses and looks through them at the Kar  BETSY
You didn't come to my dinner.  VRONSKY
I had to see my Commanding Officer.    68 BETSY
"She" didn't come either.
Vronsky watches Anna through the glasses. Countess Lydia next to her. Lydia is in her forties, sallow, no beauty, and determined.
LYDIA
. . . work never ceases for great men.
Your husband is a saint and we must all cherish him for Russia's sake.
Anna winces a smile.  LYDIA (CONT'D)
I hope you can come on afterwards--Father Kristof's report on the Chinese mission will be with lantern slides.  ANNA
I'm expected at the Tverskoys.  LYDIA
No doubt, but I'm sure Princess Betsy can wait for you, my dear.
Anna glances at Betsy's box and sees Vronsky there. The o  ANNA
Yes. In fact, I think I won't go to Betsy's.    69
Vronsky looks through Betsy's glasses.  BETSY
You're caught.  VRONSKY
I'm afraid I am becoming ridiculous.
HOUSE--DAY

Discreet Footmen move chairs to accommodate the guests wh one of the conversation circles that make a buzz in the r the samovar with her little court, including Tuskevich. T the Princess Myagkaya, stout, red-faced, outspoken, and t Lisa Merkalova and "Anna's Friend."
Vronsky arrives.  LISA MERKALOVA
Now, there's a phenomenon, look-- Anna's shadow has arrived before Anna!  ANNA'S FRIEND
I'm Anna's friend . . . but this making-up- one's-mind-to-it in public is not polite to a distinguished man like Karenin.  PRINCESS MYAGKAYA
In my opinion Karenin is a fool, and Anna is the best of us.    70 LISA MERKALOVA
And we all love you for your contrary opin- ions, Princess.
Vronsky looks around. He knows everybody in the room.  BETSY
Alexei . . . You look desperate. That's not attractive.  VRONSKY
I'm losing hope.  BETSY
Hope of what? Persuading a virtuous woman to break her marriage vows?  VRONSKY
And how is Tuskevich?  BETSY
That's not attractive either. Besides, I was never virtuous.  VRONSKY
No--you're right. She won't come. I'm going home.
The Karenin coach arrives. It's Anna arriving at Betsy's. house in almost unseemly haste. Several coaches are waiti     71
Vronsky, in a state, lets himself be carried along. Then He puts his head out of the window to shout to the Coachm  VRONSKY
Turn round!
HOUSE--NIGHT

Anna enters. Faces turn to her. She glances around. She k that Vronsky isn't there. Betsy beckons to her across the possessed, smiling, nodding to friends, pressing a hand h offering the other hand to be kissed, glides through a cr  VOICES
Wasn't Nilsson glorious? One sees that she has studied Kaulbach, of course . . .
There's something Louis Quinze about Tuskevich . . . as if he came with the furniture . . .
Betsy is smoking elegantly. She kisses Anna.  BETSY
He's gone. But you're just in time for the surprise.
There is a series of minor explosions outside and the dar into an illuminated garden lit by fountains of fire, spra guests react with cries of pleasure and applause.    72
Anna turns at once to the window near her, puts her face glass, putting her hands to her temples as if to see the   REVERSE
Her self-possessed face, lit by fireworks, falls apart in
The firework display continues for a short minute and is acknowledges the congratulations and sycophancy which are men come through the room with trays of ices.
Anna is still at the window, unaware that there is only d In the room, Betsy notes the oddity: Anna alone with her
Anna opens her eyes. She is lost for a moment, perplexed.
vronsky (O.C.) May I have the honour of bringing you an ice?
Anna turns, understanding nothing.  VRONSKY (CONT'D)
Ices are being served.  ANNA
I would prefer to try a cigarette.
She sits down. Vronsky takes out a cigarette case. He lig She tries it and coughs.    73 VRONSKY (IN FRENCH)
Courage!
Anna smiles. Puffs delicately once.  ANNA
Thank you.
She gives the cigarette to him.  ANNA (CONT'D)
I'll try another one sometime.  VRONSKY
When?
She looks at him in surprise. He dunks the cigarette in a of ice cream.  VRONSKY (CONT'D)
Where?  ANNA
Just as I was thinking your manners have improved since Moscow. You behaved badly, very badly.  VRONSKY
And who was responsible for that?
Anna gets up and walks over to Betsy's chair.  ANNA
Give me a cup of tea.   74
Betsy obediently gets up to fill a cup from the samovar. Anna. This is watched by more than one guest. Betsy hands to Anna.  BETSY
How nice--Alexei Aleksandrevich has arrived.
Karenin enters smiling. Lisa Merkalova and Anna's Friend delicious-malicious moment.  LISA MERKALOVA
I'm not sure my nerves can stand another Alexei at this moment.
As Betsy and Karenin move smilingly to greet each other, picks up the two women's intimate laughter.
Karenin remains at apparent ease, as though unaware of pe at Vronsky and Anna, and he kisses Betsy's hand. Princess meanwhile gone over to Anna. Anna likes her and is glad o  PRINCESS MYAGKAYA

So the Schuzburgs asked us to dinner. The sauce was said to have cost a thousand rou- bles, and it was ghastly. We had to ask them back. I gave them a sauce that cost eighty- five kopeks and it was a triumph.
Anna and Vronsky laugh. Princess Myagkaya moves on.  VRONSKY
Were you glad to see me or not?     75 ANNA
This must stop. You make me feel as if I were guilty of something.  VRONSKY
What do you want me to do?  ANNA
I want you to go to Moscow and beg Kitty to forgive you.  VRONSKY
No, that's not what you want. Moscow? I can do better than that. Tonight I refused a posting to Tashkent. I can change my mind, and you'll never see me again.  ANNA
If you have any thought for me, you will give me back my peace.  VRONSKY
I have no peace to give. There can be no peace for us--only misery or the greatest happiness. You are my whole life now.
She looks at him and nods slowly, as if in thought.
Betsy diplomatically leads Karenin to Anna.  BETSY
Your husband is impossible!-- his opinions are all wrong but he talks so brilliantly he wins every argument.
Anna looks up at her, hearing nothing.   76 ANNA
What?
She notices Karenin, who kisses her hand. Vronsky acknowl  KARENIN
I called to take you home.  ANNA
No, I'm staying. Send the carriage back for me.  KARENIN
Of course.
He bows to Betsy. Ignoring Vronsky, he turns away.   LATER
Vronsky is with one group of guests, Anna with another. S excited, at a small table, involved in a game of cards-- local applause. She speaks a "must go" to Betsy, and swif
Dressed for outdoors, Anna comes down the staircase. The her, opens the door and signals.
The Karenin coach moves to the entrance door, which is he Doorkeeper.   77
Anna hears hurried footsteps on the stairs. She hesitates towards the door. Vronsky catches up with her. The Doorke door open.  VRONSKY
Do you want me to go to Tashkent?
TIME--NIGHT
The two horses are restless in the freezing air. Konrad l Nobody coming.
TIME--NIGHT  VRONSKY
So I'll go to Tashkent.  ANNA
No. I don't want you to go.
She turns and goes out. Vronsky follows her.
TIME--NIGHT
Vronsky opens the carriage door for her. She gets into th door. He watches the coach go. His face.    78
Her face.
Kapitonich lets Anna in.
HOUSE--NIGHT
Karenin, reading by candlelight in his dressing gown, hea Anna's return, all the way to her entrance. He cracks his  ANNA
Waiting up? How unlike you!  KARENIN
Yes, I stayed up to talk to you.
Anna keeps going, to her dressing room/boudoir.  ANNA
What about? It's late. Where's Annushka?
He waits for her to return without her cloak.  KARENIN
I sent her off.  ANNA
Well, if you want to talk, but we should go to bed.   79 KARENIN
I have to warn you about something.  ANNA
Warn me? It's really rather late . . .  KARENIN
I wish to warn you that you may inadver- tently, by indiscretion and carelessness, give the world occasion to talk about you.  ANNA
I am not a committee. Please say what you want to tell me.  KARENIN
You and Count Vronsky attracted attention tonight.  ANNA
You don't like it when I don't talk to people, and you don't like it when I do.  KARENIN

I didn't notice anything, myself. But I saw that everyone else noticed. I consider jeal- ousy to be insulting to you and degrading to me. I have no right to inquire into your feelings. They concern only your conscience. But I'm your husband and I love you. It's my duty to remind you that we are bound together by God, and this bond can only be broken by a crime against God.     80 ANNA
I have nothing to say to you, and I'm tired.  KARENIN
And you have a son.
She returns to the boudoir. After a moment he follows.
TIME--NIGHT
Karenin finds her in her underwear, throwing aside her dr gises for that.  KARENIN
Forgive me. (TURNING ASIDE)
If I am wrong, I ask your pardon.  ANNA (LIGHTLY)
I don't know what you're talking about, and it's really too late for this. Excuse me, please.
Because she wants to undress, Karenin leaves her.
Anna lies in bed next to Karenin, elated.  ANNA (ALMOST INAUDIBLE)
Too late.   81 CLOSE--
In the next instant, seemingly in her own bed, she gasps her body has taken a blow.
The CUTS are now between a fragmented narrative of voraci BEFORE") and "prelude to sex," this being a sequence of s
Anna arrives, heavily veiled, by cab. She enters the buil
Vronsky opens his door to Anna. They don't speak. He take brings her in.
Vronsky leads Anna through the apartment to the bedroom.
Vronsky takes off Anna's outer clothes, slowly and carefu her hat and veil.   82
Anna, in underclothes, unbuttons Vronsky's shirt.
Anna and Vronsky are standing kissing passionately. He ha

Anna ends up half off the edge of Vronsky's bed, climaxin and falling to the floor. Vronsky, also half off the bed, He reaches down for her. She grasps hold of his hand, hud her, distressed to tears.  ANNA
Oh God forgive me. It's the end of everything--I've got nothing left now, only you. Remember that.  VRONSKY
Anna . . . Anna . . . how can I not remem- ber? You're my happiness.
He draws her back on to the bed, kisses her face, her sho     83 ANNA
Happiness! You murdered my happiness.
She tries to leave but he attacks her as a lover, and she  ANNA (CONT'D)
Murderer. Murderer. Go on. Go on. Go on.
She starts hitting him.  ANNA (CONT'D)
Yes. Go on. Go on. Go on.
In sunshine, a large chunk of ice loses its purchase on w floating along a stream of tiny ice floes between grassy snow, with early aconites showing.
The icy stream flows under a footbridge which has a broke Vasili, the steward, is on the bridge with a Carpenter. L displeased.  LEVIN
I thought that had been done.  VASILI
I gave the order. What can you do with these people?
Levin rides on, into an expanded prospect of fields and w   84 LATER
When Levin gets in view of the house, he is puzzled by th a three-horse sledge arriving.
The new arrival is Oblonsky, enjoying his food.  OBLONSKY
Ah--potage aux choux a la Russe!
Agafia comes in with the roast fowl.  OBLONSKY (CONT'D)
Agafia!--if you opened up in Moscow, l'Angleterre would go out of business.
Do you want news of Moscow?  LEVIN
Of Babylon? No.  OBLONSKY
You're right, what do you care? You love the country--you've got it. You love agricultur- ing, and, Lord knows, you've got it. You love shooting--you've got it. You've got every- thing you want!
Agafia, leaving, throws Levin a look (no wife).  LEVIN
All right, go on, then. Have you stopped stealing bread rolls?   85 OBLONSKY
Ballet girl, oriental type. How can I help it?  LEVIN
So, nothing new to tell me. How is--how are the Shcherbatskys?  OBLONSKY
You mean Kitty.  LEVIN
I . . . Is she engaged now?  OBLONSKY
No. Vronsky went back to St. Petersburg.
He waits for this to sink in.  OBLONSKY (CONT'D)
Kitty will be at Ergoshovo visiting Dolly in the summer. You could . . .  LEVIN
Oh yes, as if I had time in the summer! And I've got extra land this year at Kashin for the haymaking.  OBLONSKY
Kashin? That's on the Ergoshovo road, isn't it? Won't you call when Kitty is there?  LEVIN (HEATEDLY)
Especially not then. I humiliated myself once.
Now it's a row.   86 OBLONSKY

Damn you, Kostya, you love Kitty and you can't forgive her because, first, you funked it, then you bungled it, then you ran away from an eighteen-year-old girl who was made a fool of by a uniform. It's Kitty I'm sorry for--not you!  LEVIN
Her heart told her no. Did you come to shoot snipe or criticize me?
Levin and Oblonsky, with Laska, wait with their guns, a f Levin has calmed down.  LEVIN

For you, getting married is . . . a social engage- ment. Not for me. For me, it's the condition of personal happiness and living the right way. I'll never again be carried away by passion. I renounce it. I'll have to find another way . . .  OBLONSKY
Look out--here they come!
A couple of snipe come drumming over the trees. The men f ously. One snipe falls.  OBLONSKY (CONT'D)
Bad luck!
Oblonsky laughs. Despite himself, Levin laughs too. Laska   87
SPRING
Dolly has had her baby. She is holding the infant, having feeding him. Kitty is with her.  DOLLY
There. Oh, I'm sore with his feeding! Would you like to hold him?
Dolly gives the baby to Kitty, who takes him almost unwil buttons herself. Kitty's maternal instinct won't engage.  DOLLY (CONT'D)

Well, don't hold him like a parcel . . . It's Aunt Kitty, darling. . . . Little face . . . little fingers . . . look at you . . . Doesn't he make you ashamed of dwelling on your troubles . . . ?  KITTY
I have no troubles.  DOLLY
That man wasn't worth the tears, believe me.  KITTY (IRRITATED)
I don't care about him. I don't even think about him. Or her. Except to hate her.  DOLLY
Then we'll never speak of it again.
Dolly relieves Kitty of the baby.   88 DOLLY (CONT'D)
There are better men waiting for you. Stiva says . . . Kitty, my lamb, did Konstantin Levin . . . ?  KITTY ( FLARES)
What has Levin got to do with it? Anyway, I'll never get married. The whole business of . . . it's become disgusting to me . . . and look what it's done for you! Why do they call it love?  DOLLY
Because it's love.
Lovingly, she settles the baby in his crib, her face fill the bargain.
SPRING

A lovers' idyll, by a stream on a warm day. Anna, lightly a cigarette, watches Vronsky fill his wineglass from a te stream. There is a pony trap which brought them. He comes her. She kisses him.  ANNA
I want you to. I don't care about it.  VRONSKY
You should care. You're not supposed to.    89 ANNA
Pooh! Who says?  VRONSKY
Everybody. Doctors.
She laughs and throws her cigarette into the stream.  ANNA
You're squeamish. You a soldier! Would you faint?  VRONSKY
Anyway, someone might be watching.
Anna looks all around. Vast emptiness. She lifts a dock l it. She looks up at the sky.  ANNA
But I'm damned anyway.  VRONSKY
I'm not. I'm blessed.
Anna pushes him onto his back and straddles him.  ANNA
You love me.  VRONSKY
Yes.  ANNA
Only me.    90 VRONSKY
No.  ANNA
Apart from Frou-Frou.  VRONSKY
Yes.
Anna holds his face between her hands and works her body  ANNA
But me more than your horse?  VRONSKY
Yes.  ANNA
Are you happy?  VRONSKY
Yes.  ANNA
And you love me?  VRONSKY
Yes.  ANNA
How much?  VRONSKY
This much.
Anna drags the front of her skirts out of her way.   91 ANNA
This much?  VRONSKY
Yes.  ANNA
This much?  VRONSKY
Yes.  ANNA
This much?  VRONSKY
Yes.  ANNA
This much? And this much? And this much?  VRONSKY
Yes.  ANNA ( FIERCELY)
And . . . this . . . much . . . ?
She falls on him. He strokes her hair.
Her hand comes into view, the index finger bloody. She ca lips with it. She kisses his lips clean, and rolls off hi     92 ANNA (CONT'D)
So this is love. This.
SUMMER
Korney brings Countess Lydia. Karenin comes from behind h invite her to a chair.  KARENIN
Countess . . . I thought you would be at Peterhof now.  LYDIA
I've come from there. I'm distressed that you haven't taken your usual house this year.  KARENIN
Anna wanted a change. She is spending the summer at Tsarskoe.  LYDIA
Near Princess Betsy. And . . .
Karenin waits.  LYDIA (CONT'D)
The Guards are in summer camp at Tsarskoe.
Karenin waits.     93 LYDIA (CONT'D)
Alexei Alexandrovich, forgive me but you are too tolerant! Your wife . . .
Karenin affects surprise.  KARENIN
Oh, is this about my wife?
He smiles at her.  KARENIN (CONT'D)
My wife is beyond reproach. She is, after all, my wife.
Countess Lydia gets the message. She rises to go. Karenin and accompanies her to the door. She leaves him, and his way to his disturbance.

The Commanding Officer is throwing a party for his office ing, Soldier Servants, a crowded table on the large veran ers in white linen tunics performing operetta and folk so party spirit, is with Petritsky and another friend, Yashv
An officer we don't know is, surprisingly, hailed as "Vro Vronsky's elder brother, Alexander. He gestures "Later!" sky. The brothers embrace.  ALEXANDER
Alyosha . . . a message from Maman. Her friend Princess Sorokina has a house here, and a virgin daughter, that's not part of the   94
message, but they'll all be at the races and you're expected to supper afterwards.
The song ends and Demin, half drunk, climbs on the table, and a toast.  DEMIN
Gentlemen--I give you--the regiment!
General uproar. "The regiment."
On a garden bench where the noise of the party is quieter Alexander talk.  ALEXANDER
I heard you turned down a promotion.  VRONSKY
That was Maman interfering.  ALEXANDER
Yes. And now she's come up with a princess for you. (SERIOUSLY)

Alexei--we're brothers, so don't take offence. Getting married puts the pack on your back--it leaves your hands free for climbing the ladder. Getting serious about a married woman is like carrying your pack in your arms.     95 VRONSKY
So they talk about me. I'm leaving, Sasha.  ALEXANDER
An assignation?  VRONSKY
Come on, I'll introduce you.
Vronsky with Alexander beside him clucks his tongue at th of a stable and calls softly for Frou-Frou. There's a sti mare's head appears. Vronsky opens the door.  ALEXANDER
Beautiful. A man would come to no harm. Do you think you'll win tomorrow?  VRONSKY
Makhotin's Gladiator is favourite, sixteen hands--Frou-Frou looks dainty beside him, but she's got heart. Haven't you, my darling?
He kisses Frou-Frou.
Vronsky sees Anna before she sees him. He pauses to look her beauty, full of love for her. She is lost in thought.     96 VRONSKY
Anna.
She has not been expecting him. She is concerned.  ANNA
Alexei, what is it?
He shakes his head: nothing. She comes to him and hides h breast. He holds her tight, taking her hand and kissing i  VRONSKY
I couldn't bear not to see you before the race.
She hugs him, kissing his tunic.  VRONSKY (CONT'D)
What were you thinking about?
She continues to hide her face. He lifts her face.  VRONSKY (CONT'D)
Tell me.  ANNA
I'm pregnant.
Vronsky presses her hand to his face.  VRONSKY
Ah . . . My love.
He kisses her brow and her eyes.     97 VRONSKY (CONT'D)
Well, love was never a game to us. Here's an end to living in corners, existing day to day on lies. Yes, now we can be together.  ANNA
How can we, Alexei?  VRONSKY
Tell Karenin everything.  ANNA
Do you think my husband will make you a present of me?  VRONSKY
Leave him.  ANNA
Leave him and be your mistress?  VRONSKY
Yes. Run away.  ANNA
I would never see my son again. The laws are made by husbands and fathers.  VRONSKY
What, then? I'll never forgive myself for your unhappiness.
Anna looks into his face.     98 ANNA
Unhappiness? I'm like a starving beggar who has been given food.
She smiles rapturously.  ANNA (CONT'D)
I unhappy? No, this is my happiness!
She kisses him deeply.
TSARSKOE--DAY

It's a good maze. Anna and Serozha are running, laughing, hedges. It's a game. She is trying to find her way to him hedge divides them. Serozha darts away from her, runs int doubles back. She spots him, follows him, and now he has
Serozha finds his way out of the maze and is confronted b  KARENIN
How are you, young man? Your tutor doesn't seem to be in evidence. We'll have a look at your lesson books.
Anna, coming out of the maze, sees Karenin, recovers.  ANNA
Alexei!--you got away at last. Can you stay?  KARENIN
Why . . . ?
Serozha looks scared to tears. Anna kisses him.   99 ANNA
Go and find Vasily Lukich.
Serozha runs into the house.  ANNA (CONT'D)
I have to change. Princess Betsy is sending her trap for me. Would you like to come?-- she's taking me to watch the race.
Karenin smiles coldly.  KARENIN
Races, surely. No, I'll come on later, and then I must get back to town.
Anna returns to the house. She wipes her kissed hand on h
This is a rough-and-ready racecourse but the venue for a sion, with a grandstand for top people and a grander sect for greater comfort, for members of the Imperial family. parade for some.
The racecourse itself is an oval approached by a straight fences, water-jumps, etc., of various difficulty. The "jo the Guards, the Hussars and other regiments.

Among them is Vronsky, attended by a Trainer who is fussi Frou's bridle and calming her. Vronsky looks with interes ful horse which must be Gladiator, with Captain Makhotin saddle. Makhotin and Vronsky greet each other with a nod.    100 KARENIN
-- arrives at the races . . . making his way towards the raising his hat to acquaintances . . . his eyes busy look reaches the front and looks up at the Ladies' Stand.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE LADIES' STAND, THE RACES, SAME TIME--

text: DAY
Anna and Betsy are here, and, not far away, so are Counte the Princesses Sorokina: the mother is a fading fortyish; eighteen, blonde and pretty.
Below the ladies section is a planked standing area for g may stand to watch the races from the stepped aisle of th Soldiers, Horse People and Locals watch from the turf.
A race is flowing towards the winning post, with accompan tion, but it is clear from Anna's detachment, exchanging that this is not Vronsky's race.   KARENIN
--looks up to the ladies' stand. Betsy smiles at him in g seems unaware.
Countess Vronsky appraises the young princess.  COUNTESS VRONSKY
Exquisite creature . . . you really ought to be the spoil of victory today . . .
The young princess smiles at her. Countess Vronsky turns the Starting Post.   101

location: NEAR THE STARTING POST, THE RACES, SAME

text: TIME--DAY
. . . Vronsky mounts Frou-Frou. The Riders move to the st   KARENIN
. . . watches Anna who is looking through her glasses tow Post while the current race finishes to cheers.
Anna's anxious attention turns to a horse and rider who f down the course-- and to the ambulance wagon (with a red on it) . . .
Karenin mounts the steps of the aisle, raising his hat to Anna ignores him.
On the wooden boards below, where gentlemen are watching, up to Betsy.  OBLONSKY
Princess! A bet! What do you fancy in the next?  BETSY
Kusolev.  OBLONSKY
I'm on Vronsky. A pair of gloves?     102 BETSY
Done! (TO ANNA)
Alexander Vronsky . . .
In the aisle at the top of the stand, Karenin watches as:
Vronsky's brother Alexander, escorting his wife, Varya, b Betsy, but significantly Varya succeeds in not noticing t

location: STARTING POST, THE RACES, SAME TIME--DAY

text: The riders line up . . . and they're off.   VRONSKY'S POV

The stands and spectators are distant, the first fence co on either side. His neighbour falls at the fence but Frou Gladiator half a length in front. The next fence is comin and Frou-Frou jump cleanly but a following horse falls ba

location: LADIES' STAND, THE RACES, SAME TIME--DAY

text: Spectators on either side of Anna and those behind and in

Anna reacts not at all. Her gaze through her glasses stay on Vronsky. Karenin notes this, and from then on his atte Anna. When the horses come opposite the stand, she lowers follows Frou-Frou taking the lead from Gladiator.   103 VRONSKY
-- eases Frou-Frou past Gladiator. The horses take the ne   LADIES' STAND
With one hand Anna grips her folded fan.
Karenin's face is a mask as he watches Anna unconsciously it. She raises her glasses.
Frou-Frou approaches the last fence with Gladiator half a on the near side to Anna.   VRONSKY
-- working the reins, rising and falling in rhythm with t ahead to the winning post, and before knowing it he makes the rhythm, dropping back into the saddle and raising the as Frou-Frou takes off.

Frou-Frou rises, Gladiator rises. Frou-Frou disappears. G the fence in Anna's foreground. Simultaneously, there are exclamations all around her-- OFF CAMERA-- and the view t the glasses zigzags in search of Frou-Frou, impeded by ho fence.    104
She lowers the glasses and sees Frou-Frou on the ground, Vronsky on the ground.   COUNTESS VRONSKY
-- sees this, too, her mouth set tight with contempt.   KARENIN
--looks shocked. Almost in the same moment he hears Anna' cry, conspicuous in the hubbub that follows the crowd's e  ANNA
Alexei . . . !  KARENIN
I'm here.
This is adroit. He comes down several steps and pushes th but Anna has lost control, trying to escape like a bird b  KARENIN (CONT'D)
Would you like to leave?
Anna ignores him, puts her glasses to her eyes, searching
Vronsky extricates himself from his broken horse and, in tion, tries to pull Frou-Frou to her feet by the reins. F to get up but her back is broken. Officials, officers, an running.   105 ANNA
. . . sees an Officer hurrying to the Imperial party to r  ANNA
Stiva! What are they saying?  OBLONSKY
Vronsky's unhurt--but the horse . . .
Anna relapses into sobs, attempting to hide her face behi fan. Betsy gives Anna her fan.   VRONSKY
--is restrained by an Officer.  OFFICER
Her back's broken!
The Officer takes a pistol from his holster. Vronsky, enr takes the pistol from him.   KARENIN
--persists with Anna.  KARENIN
I'm asking you . . . if you wish to go . . .
He touches Anna's arm. She jerks it away.     106 ANNA
No, leave me alone.  BETSY
I'll bring her home, Alexei.  KARENIN (SMILING POLITELY)
Excuse me, Princess, but Anna is not well and I want her to come with me.
A gunshot is heard from the course. Anna turns her tear-s towards it.
Anna's hysteria has solidified into a blank despair. Kare to pretend that nothing important has happened.  KARENIN
You know . . . they say the Emperor dis- approves of the races . . . the danger of injury . . . but I . . .
Anna looks at him contemptuously.  ANNA
What?  KARENIN
I'm saying there is a value in manly sport, for the military--     107 ANNA
I don't understand.  KARENIN
In my opinion, it's not the sport itself that's wrong, it's the spectacle, it's making a cruel spectacle out of--  ANNA
What are you talking about?
Karenin changes tack.  KARENIN
I have to tell you--  ANNA
Yes.  KARENIN
I have to tell you, you behaved improperly today.  ANNA
And how was that?
She has raised her voice. He raises a warning finger, and communication window behind the coachman's box.  KARENIN
By making plain your feelings when one of the riders fell. Your conduct was improper. It must not occur again. I have said it before.
Anna smiles faintly. He is misled by that.   108 KARENIN (CONT'D)
You are going to say my concern is unneces- sary and ridiculous. You are my wife. I am wrong to think that . . . yes--perhaps I was mistaken.
Anna looks at him despairingly.  ANNA
No, you were not mistaken. I love him. I am his mistress. I can't bear you, I'm afraid of you, I hate you. Do what you like to me.
Karenin is literally winded--gasping for breath, slowly g ing under control. Anna huddles away from him in her corn recovers himself only to the point of sitting stock-still not moving.
The coach lurches, unbalancing him so that he is pushed a recoils as if from a contamination.
The coach slows. The coach stops. A Servant comes to the the door.  KARENIN
Wait, please. Move away.
The Servant backs off.  KARENIN (CONT'D)

I will not have a scandal. Therefore . . . You will not see . . . this man again. You will behave in such a way that nothing is known against you, by society or by the servants. In return, you will keep the privileges of a   109
wife--and the duties. Tomorrow you will return home. That is all.
Anna gets out of the coach and runs into the maze.
Anna comes to Vronsky. She is still shaken by the showdow Karenin in his coach, but is now overtaken by concern for fall.  ANNA
Are you hurt?
Vronsky shakes his head. He is moved by the sight of her, desire, but in her embrace he detects something new, a ne  VRONSKY
What's happened?  ANNA
I told him I'm your mistress.
Vronsky lifts her face, strokes her cheek. He waits.  ANNA (CONT'D)
He thinks I can give you up and go on living.
He embraces her for that, relieved, grateful, loving--und she is not going to give him up.     110 VRONSKY
No, you cannot.
Imperial hands (the Tsar's for all we know) place over Ka broad red ribbon from which hangs a heavy medal. Karenin
At an ornate doorway a Major-Domo announces.  MAJOR DOMO
Their Excellencies Minister Karenin and Madame Karenin!

Karenin, wearing his medal, and Anna smile their way into patter of polite applause. Further grandees are being ann applauded . . . Prince and Princess Berghatskoy . . . Amb lain . . . Baron and Baroness Verdlov . . . Prince and Pr  BETSY
Alexei Aleksandrevich . . . congratulations. You're the only man my husband would do this for.  ANNA
(To Prince Tverskoy) Tell me your latest find for your library.  PRINCE TVERSKOY
Not in front of the Princess.    111
Betsy draws Anna away for a moment.  BETSY
I can tell you're happy. You've put on a little weight.  ANNA
Both true.
NIGHT
Anna, in the same dress, kisses Serozha tenderly so as no leaves the room.
TIME--NIGHT
Anna enters the suite where Karenin, in his dressing gown book. He is elated by his evening.  KARENIN
Time for bed!
NIGHT
Anna is in bed. Karenin is getting ready for bed. Anna li sively to the little noises of Karenin's pre-coital prepa     112 KARENIN
. . . not that I care for decorations but . . .  ANNA
Alexei . . . I can't . . . I'm sorry . . . But I'm his wife now. (she turns to him) I am having his child.
Karenin stares at her. He turns back to the open drawer a back the way they were. He locks the drawer. He puts on h and leaves the room. Anna waits a moment and follows him.

head_text.subj: INT. SITTING ROOM, KARENIN HOUSE, SAME TIME--

text: NIGHT
It's dark. Anna hears the crack of his knuckles and can s sitting in the dark.  KARENIN
Tell me what I did to deserve this.
A prospect: next to a country road, a large expanse of me mown forty swathes at a time by forty mowers swinging the in unison.

CLOSER--Levin is suffering but keeping up, bathed in pers place is behind an old man, Theodore, who is scything as Just in time for Levin, Theodore calls a halt and takes L sharpen it with a whetstone. Levin attracts a few grins a    113 YOUNG PEASANT
Konstantin Dmitrich, you'll know your rows when the field's all done!
Levin's row has stalks of differing heights between the e either side. There is some laughter, but the men are unea
It's time to stop for the day. More tomorrow. The Mowers walk back across the large meadow of cut swathes. From th tion, a crowd of Village Women are coming to meet them ca drink.

A fire has been lit. The Mowers eat their meal in the com Serafina tends to a cooking pot in the firelight. Levin w He has settled down at a discreet distance from the men. is caught by a grown-up Boy and his young Wife who have c slightly apart. He is charmed by them, watching the girl
Theodore comes to Levin with a jug. Levin takes a swig.  LEVIN
How many mowers is it, Theodore?  THEODORE
Forty-two, master. In your father's time it was work for two days for thirty men . . . (SLYLY)
. . . though he never picked up a scythe himself.   114 LEVIN
The men don't like me for it.  THEODORE
They like what they're used to.  LEVIN
It settles me.  THEODORE
How is that, master?  LEVIN
When I'm mowing, I don't ask myself why I'm here.  THEODORE
You're here to be master, Konstantin Dmi- trich, to be your father's son, and father to a son who will be master after you, as it has always been by the grace of God.  LEVIN
My father owned you, Theodore. My grand- father owned your father. Owned you like chattels, to be bought and sold. Was that by the grace of God?  THEODORE

It was. Those were good times when your father had the keeping of us. That's my youngest you were looking at there. His young life is perilous now since the Free- dom came and work must be found.    115 LEVIN
It's true I was looking at him.  THEODORE (LAUGHS)
At his wife too, I dare say.
Levin is abashed, found out.  LEVIN
They look happier than I've ever been. Is it living simply that I'm looking for?
Night under the stars. Some of the men have gone, some ha the night. The cooking fire is burning out. Levin remains watching, thinking: drawn to "the simple life."
Levin wakes . . . woken by hoofbeats and the jingle of ha
Levin sees a coach coming towards him. The coach comes ne boxes strapped to the roof.
Levin sees that a young woman is looking out of the side on to the white ribbons of her bonnet. He sees that it is Ergoshovo. (Princess Shcherbatsky is also inside, dozing.
The coach passes on, leaving Levin lovelorn, the dawn lig sight of Kitty has turned him round again.    116
AUTUMN
Vronsky stands at the entrance to the platform holding a for a train. He looks pretty fed up.

As before, the set-up is a small stage, a small auditoriu drinking, cruising, etc., a combination of music hall and tables. Vronsky is here as the escort of a Foreign Prince ing a "risquГ©" show with Can-Can Girls, much relished by
Vronsky's glance casts about in the gloom. The champagne sky spots a trio--Lisa Merkalova, Betsy, and Stremov, a p Karenin's rival.
